questions.text: A CT scan of the patient was given. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extradural hemorrhage CT shows a large right extradural haematoma . There are widespread cerebral contusions, most prominent in the left frontal lobe . There is traumatic subarachnoid blood in the third and lateral ventricles .

Highyeild:

Extradural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency. It results from an artery, vein, or venous sinus rupture associated with a skull fracture. The classical injury is a fracture to the thin squamous temporal bone, with associated damage to the middle meningeal artery. Presentation : Transient loss of consciousness is typical, and the patient may then present in the subsequent lucid interval with a headache but without any neurological deficit. As the hematoma expands, compensation is exhausted with rapid deterioration. There is contralateral hemiparesis, a reduced conscious level, and ipsilateral pupillary dilatation , the cardinal signs of brain compression and herniation. Although this ‘talk and die’ pattern of deterioration occurs in only one-third of cases, it is critically important to recognize the potential for rapid avoidable secondary brain injury in patients who present neurologically intact. Diagnosis : On CT, extradural hematomas appear as a lentiform (lens-shaped or biconvex) hyperdense lesion between the skull and the brain, constrained by the adherence of the dura to the head. A mass effect may be evident, with compression of the surrounding brain and midline shift. Areas of mixed density suggest active bleeding . A skull fracture will usually be apparent. Treatment : Open craniectomy for evacuation of the congealed clot and hemostasis generally is indicated for EDH. In some cases, EDH can be caused by self-limited bony venous bleeding that may not require surgical intervention. Typically, patients who meet the following criteria may be managed conservatively: clot volume <30 cm, maximum thickness <1.5 cm, and GCS score >8 . Prognosis : Prognosis after successful evacuation is better for EDH than subdural hematoma (SDH). EDHs are associated with lower-energy trauma with less resultant primary brain injury. Good outcomes may be seen in 85% to 90% of patients with rapid CT scans and intervention.11 In some cases, EDH can also be caused by dural venous sinus tears that rapidly expand and are typically associated with a high degree of morbidity when treated surgically

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Subdural Hematoma On head CT scan, the clot is bright(Hyperdense) or mixed-density, crescent-shaped (lunate), may have a less distinct border, and does not cross the midline due to the presence of the falx. Most SDHs occur over the cerebral hemispheres but may also occur between the hemispheres or layer over the tentorium. Option: C. Most Common type of Intracranial hemorrhage is Intracerebral hemorrhage Option: D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Trauma is the commonest cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and this is managed conservatively.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is posted for cardiac surgery. Which is the preferred drug for prophylaxis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cefazolin The preferred drug for prophylaxis in cardiac surgery is Cefazolin . Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic with a broad spectrum of activity against Gram-positive bacteria, including Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species, the most common causes of surgical site infections. It is also effective against some Gram-negative bacteria. Cefazolin has a long half-life , allowing for a single preoperative dose to prevent surgical site infections effectively. The American Heart Association recommends using cefazolin as the preferred prophylactic antibiotic in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.

Highyeild:

Prophylactic antibiotics are used when there is a risk of wound contamination with bacteria during surgery. Points to be remembered in the antibiotic prophylaxis are as follows : Not required in clean surgery unless a prosthesis is implanted Use antibiotics that are effective against expected pathogens within local hospital guidelines Plan for single-shot intravenous administration at induction of anesthesia Repeat only during extended operations or if there is excessive blood loss Patients with heart valve disease or a prosthesis should be protected from bacteremia caused by dental work, urethral instrumentation, or visceral surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Penicillin G is also effective against Streptococcus species but is less effective against Staphylococcus species and Gram-negative bacteria. Penicillin G has a narrow spectrum of activity and requires multiple doses to be effective. Therefore, it is not the preferred choice for prophylaxis in cardiac surgery. Option B: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic effective against some Gram-positive bacteria, including Streptococcus species. However, it is not effective against Staphylococcus species or Gram-negative bacteria. Erythromycin also has a shorter half-life than cefazolin, meaning multiple doses are required for prevention. Therefore, erythromycin is not the preferred choice for prevention in cardiac surgery. Option D: Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that is effective against some Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. However, it is less effective than cefazolin against Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species. Doxycycline also has a shorter half-life than cefazolin, meaning multiple doses are required for prevention. Therefore, doxycycline is not the preferred choice for prophylaxis in cardiac surgery.

questions.text: Which is the most common complication following the first significant vessel ligation during abdominoperineal resection in the CA rectum?

options.label: D
options.text: Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation

questions.correct_answer: D. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is a surgical procedure that involves complete removal of the rectum, anal canal, and sphincter apparatus, resulting in the creation of a permanent colostomy. The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is the first vessel usually ligated during the procedure. However, a high IMA ligation during APR can cause sympathetic dysfunction, leading to retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction due to injury to the superior hypogastric nerve. APR is often preferred in elderly patients with distal rectal cancer and poor sphincter function, as it offers a better quality of life. However, complications such as higher recurrence rates compared to low anterior resection, anastomotic leaks or dehiscences, necrosis of the transposed colon, bleeding, and strictures can occur. The rectum and genitourinary system are supplied by the sympathetic innervation from L1, L2, and L3, which form the superior hypogastric plexus. These nerves divide into left and right hypogastric nerves at the sacral promontory, providing innervation to the rectum and genitourinary system. Injuries to the pelvic mesh, nerve originates, or periprostatic net during APR can lead to erectile dysfunction, impotence, atonic bladder, sexual dysfunction, and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: H/O trauma. Eye opening of painful stimulus, inappropriate words, flexion on pain. What is GCS?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E2V3M3 Eye opening of painful stimulus - E2 Inappropriate words - V3 Flexion on pain. - M3

Highyeild:

Glasgow Coma Scale Score : The initial assessment of the trauma patient includes the primary survey, resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care. Neurosurgical evaluation begins during the primary survey with the determination of the GCS score (usually referred to simply as the GCS) for the patient. The GCS is determined by adding the scores of the best responses of the patient in each of the three categories. The motor score ranges from 1 to 6, verbal from 1 to 5, and eyes from 1 to 4. The GCS, therefore, ranges from 3 to 15 Tracheal intubation or severe facial or eye swelling can impede verbal and eye responses. In these circumstances, the patient is given a score of 1 with a modifier, such as verbal “1T” where T = tube

questions.text: Alkali injury of esophagus on ingestion of poison by maid. She presents with total dysphagia. Next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Feeding jejunostomy The next step in the management of a patient with total dysphagia due to alkali injury of the esophagus caused by ingestion of poison would be to perform a feeding jejunostomy. Ingestion of alkali substances can cause severe damage to the esophagus, leading to total dysphagia or the inability to swallow. The initial management of these patients typically involves supportive care, including airway protection, fluid resuscitation, and pain control. However, since these injuries can lead to stricture formation, which can cause persistent dysphagia, additional management is often required. Feeding jejunostomy is a surgical procedure in which a tube is placed through the abdominal wall and into the jejunum, the second part of the small intestine. This tube allows for enteral feeding, bypassing the esophagus and stomach, and delivering nutrients directly to the small intestine. In patients with total dysphagia, this is necessary to prevent malnutrition and maintain adequate caloric intake while the esophagus heals. Once the esophagus has healed, further management, such as endoscopic dilation or surgical reconstruction, may be necessary to restore swallowing function.

Highyeild:

Refeeding syndrome Patient is considered to be at risk of developing refeeding syndrome with EITHER One or more of the following: BMI <16 kg/m² Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding Two of more of the following: BMI <18.5 kg/m² Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics

Explanation for incorrect options:- Stenting of the lesion (option A) may be considered in some cases, but it is not the first-line management for total dysphagia caused by alkali injury. Gastrojejunostomy (option B) and esophagojejunostomy (option C) are surgical procedures that may be necessary in cases of severe esophageal injury, but they are not the first-line management for total dysphagia.

questions.text: Sudden onset chest pain radiating to the scapular region and neck. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aortic dissection The sudden onset of chest pain radiating to the scapular region and neck is a symptom that can occur in several medical conditions. However, one of the most important conditions that should be considered in this scenario is aortic dissection . Therefore, the correct answer is option A, aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a medical emergency that occurs when there is a tear in the inner lining of the aorta, the large blood vessel that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body. Symptoms can include sudden onset of severe chest pain that is often described as tearing or ripping and may radiate to the back, scapular region, or neck. Other symptoms may include dizziness, weakness, shortness of breath, or loss of consciousness. Acute coronary syndrome (option B) is another condition that can cause chest pain, but it is typically localized to the chest and may radiate to the left arm or jaw. Pulmonary embolism (option C) can cause chest pain, but it is usually associated with shortness of breath and may not radiate to the scapular region and neck. Cardiac arrest (option D) is a sudden loss of consciousness and absence of pulse and breathing and is not typically associated with chest pain that radiates to the scapular region and neck.

Highyeild:

Clinical Features: Acute aortic dissection: characterized by sudden, severe, tearing pain, accompanied by sweating. Pain may be felt in the front or back of the chest, often in the interscapular region, and may shift as the dissection progresses. Other symptoms may include fainting, shortness of breath, and weakness. Physical examination may reveal hypertension or hypotension, absence of pulses, aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, and neurological symptoms caused by carotid artery obstruction or spinal cord ischemia.

Extraedge:

Ascending aortic dissection may be detected by the presence of a widened superior mediastinum on a chest X-ray. Pleural effusion, usually on the left side and typically serosanguineous, may be present. CT angiography is the imaging modality of choice for stable patients. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred in unstable patients.

questions.text: CECT showing chronic pancreatitis and stone, what is the management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy The management of chronic pancreatitis with a pancreatic stone depends on the location and extent of the disease, as well as the patient's symptoms and overall health. The goal of treatment is to relieve pain, improve pancreatic function, and prevent complications. In the scenario presented, a pancreatic stone has been identified on contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) in a patient with chronic pancreatitis. In such a scenario, the most appropriate management would be longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy . Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy, also known as the Puestow procedure, involves creating a side-to-side anastomosis between the pancreas and a loop of jejunum, bypassing the obstructed pancreatic duct. This can relieve pain, prevent recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis, and improve pancreatic function. This procedure is typically reserved for patients with refractory pain or recurrent acute pancreatitis, who have failed conservative management.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Head coring (option A) and pancreatoduodenectomy (option B) are surgical options for patients with chronic pancreatitis with involvement of the head of the pancreas, but may not be appropriate in all cases. Distal pancreatectomy (option D) is typically reserved for patients with localized disease involving the tail of the pancreas.

Trypsinogen is normally inhibited and destroyed by SPINK1 if it becomes activated prematurely within the pancreas. Diagnosis is confirmed on abdominal CT imaging, which can show pancreatic calcifications, ductal strictures, and ductal dilatation. A “chain of lakes” appearance can sometimes be seen, which is caused by the alternating dilation and stricture of the main pancreatic duct. Pancreatic function tests (e.g., fecal elastase-1 measurement, 72-hour quantitative fecal fat test) can be used to assess the degree of pancreatic exocrine and enzyme deficiency Alcohol use disorder is the most common etiology of chronic pancreatitis, accounting for 60–70% of cases. A loss-of-function mutation in SPINK1 is also linked to idiopathic pancreatitis. Some patients with idiopathic chronic pancreatitis have mutations in the CFTR gene. Patients with hereditary pancreatitis and those who develop pancreatitis at a young age, especially if they smoke tobacco, are at a significantly increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer. questions.text: What is the good prognostic factor in breast ca
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ER + In breast cancer, ER (estrogen receptor) positivity is considered a good prognostic factor. Therefore, the correct answer is option D, ER+. ER is a protein that is present in some breast cancer cells and helps them grow in response to the hormone estrogen. Tumors that are ER-positive tend to grow more slowly and are less likely to spread to other parts of the body. Additionally, patients with ER-positive breast cancer may respond well to hormone therapy, which can block the effects of estrogen on cancer cells.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- On the other hand, p53 positivity (option A) and high KI-67 (option B) are considered negative prognostic factors in breast cancer. p53 is a tumor suppressor gene that helps to regulate cell division, and mutations in this gene can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and the development of cancer. KI-67 is a protein that is expressed in actively dividing cells, and high levels of KI-67 are associated with more aggressive tumors. BRCA1 (option C) is a tumor suppressor gene that is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer when mutated. While BRCA1 mutation is a risk factor for developing breast cancer, it is not considered a prognostic factor for breast cancer survival.

questions.text: Image of proptosis given with midline neck swelling. What will be the finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyroid receptor antibody The image of proptosis with midline neck swelling suggests the possibility of a thyroid mass or goiter. Therefore, the appropriate test to perform would be a thyroid function test along with thyroid autoantibodies. Out of the options given, the most relevant autoantibody for this scenario would be option A, anti-thyroglobulin antibody (TgAb) . Anti-TgAb is an autoantibody that is commonly found in patients with thyroid autoimmune disease and thyroid nodules.

Highyeild:

Grave's Disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism and is caused by autoantibodies that stimulate TSH-R . It is an autoimmune disease that has a strong familial predisposition . Females are more commonly affected, with the peak incidence occurring between 40-60 years of age. The disease is characterized by thyrotoxicosis, diffuse goiter, and extrathyroidal conditions such as ophthalmopathy, dermopathy, thyroid acropachy, gynecomastia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (TPOAb) (option B) and thyroid receptor antibody (TRAbs) (option C) are also autoantibodies associated with thyroid autoimmune disease, but they are not specifically related to thyroid nodules or masses. Anti-TSH antibody (option D) is not a commonly used test in clinical practice as it is not associated with any specific thyroid disease or condition.

Extraedge:

Graves' disease may have multiple triggers, including iodine excess, bacterial or viral infections, the post-partum state, and lithium therapy. The disease is associated with specific human leukocyte antigen (HLA) genes, including HLA-B8, HLA-DR3, HLA-DQA10501, and CTLA-4 . However, HLA-DRB10701 is protective against the development of Graves' disease.

questions.text: Chest X ray with right upper lobe tumor. Symptoms of right hand tingling & ptosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancoast tumor The symptoms of right hand tingling and ptosis along with the finding of a right upper lobe tumor on chest X-ray suggest the possibility of a Pancoast tumor . A Pancoast tumor is a type of lung cancer that occurs in the upper part of the lung, near the chest wall. It can cause symptoms such as shoulder pain, arm pain, hand weakness, and Horner's syndrome (which includes ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis). The tumor can also cause compression of nearby nerves, which can lead to tingling or numbness in the affected arm.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Tuberculosis (option B) and pneumonia (option C) are also possible causes of a lung mass on chest X-ray, but they are not typically associated with the symptoms of right hand tingling and ptosis. Cervical rib (option D) can cause similar symptoms but is less likely to be associated with a lung mass.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis causes cancer
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholangiocarcinoma Clonorchis sinensis is a parasitic flatworm that can infect the bile ducts of humans and other animals. Chronic infection with this parasite can lead to a range of health problems, including cholangiocarcinoma, or cancer of the bile ducts. Cholangiocarcinoma : Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis is a major risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma, a type of cancer that develops in the bile ducts. The parasite can cause inflammation and damage to the bile ducts over time, which can increase the risk of cancer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Gallbladder cancer: While Clonorchis sinensis infection is not typically associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer, chronic inflammation and other complications associated with the infection can sometimes lead to gallbladder disease. Option C. Urinary bladder cancer: Clonorchis sinensis infection is not typically associated with an increased risk of urinary bladder cancer. The parasite primarily infects the bile ducts and liver. Option D. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is a pus-filled pocket that forms in the liver due to a bacterial infection, which can be life-threatening if left untreated. It causes symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting and is diagnosed through imaging tests and blood tests. Treatment involves antibiotics and drainage of the abscess. Prevention involves maintaining good hygiene and avoiding risky behavior. It is histologically classified into three types: mass forming, intraductal growing, and periductal infiltrating. Bile duct cancer is rare, but its incidence is increasing. Most patients present with abnormal liver function tests or jaundice. Diagnosis is typically made through imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Unfortunately, complete surgical excision is possible in less than 10% of cases, and the majority of patients receive palliative care only. The prognosis for bile duct cancer is poor , with 90% of patients dying within one year from liver failure or biliary sepsis. Adjuvant chemoradiation therapy has a limited role in the management of this disease.

questions.text: Ca breast. Prognostic factors. Good Prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Er positive Breast cancer is a complex disease, and the prognosis or the likelihood of recovery depends on several factors. ER (estrogen receptor) positive status is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer. It means that the cancer cells have receptors that bind to the hormone estrogen, which can help slow down the growth of the cancer cells. ER-positive breast cancers can be treated with hormone therapy, which targets the estrogen receptor and can improve the chances of survival.

Highyeild:

Prognostic factors for breast cancer, including: Histological type: The most common type of breast cancer is invasive carcinoma of no special type ( NST ), while rare histological variants like colloid or mucinous carcinoma, medullary carcinoma, and tubular carcinoma usually carry a better prognosis. Histological grade : The degree of mitosis can be detected by the Ki-67 mitotic index, which can be used to determine the histological grade of the tumor. Higher-grade tumors are generally associated with a worse prognosis. Hormone receptor status : Tumor cells that express estrogen receptors ( ER positive ) and/or progesterone receptors ( PR positive ) may respond better to hormonal therapies, which can improve the prognosis. HER2/neu status: Tumor cells that overexpress the human epidermal growth factor receptor 2/neu (HER2/neu positive) may be more aggressive, but targeted therapies like trastuzumab can improve the prognosis. Androgen receptor status : Tumor cells that express androgen receptors (AR positive) may have a better prognosis. Lymph node involvement: Breast cancer that has spread to the lymph nodes is generally associated with a worse prognosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- P53 is a tumor suppressor gene that plays a critical role in preventing the development of cancer. Mutations in the p53 gene can lead to the formation and growth of cancer cells. In breast cancer, the presence of p53 mutations is associated with a worse prognosis and a higher risk of recurrence. Ki67 is a protein that is used as a marker of cell proliferation. In breast cancer, a higher level of Ki67 is associated with a more aggressive tumor and a worse prognosis. BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene that is involved in repairing damaged DNA. Mutations in BRCA1 can increase the risk of developing breast cancer, and women with BRCA1 mutations may have a higher risk of developing a more aggressive form of breast cancer.

questions.text: Rectal polyp child. On histological examination of colonic epithelium with mucin, an increased number of glands and inflammatory cells was found. It is an example of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hamartoma A hamartoma is a benign tumor-like growth composed of an overgrowth of normal tissues that are normally present in the affected area, without any malignant potential. In the case of a rectal polyp in a child with an increased number of glands and inflammatory cells in the colonic epithelium, it is likely that the hamartoma is composed of abnormal glandular tissue with accompanying inflammation. Hamartomas can occur in various tissues and organs throughout the body and may present clinically with a wide range of symptoms, depending on the location and size of the hamartoma.

Highyeild:

Hamartoma: a type of benign tumor composed of disorganized but mature cells native to the organ in which it arises. It is usually asymptomatic but can cause symptoms depending on its location and size. In the case of colorectal hamartomas, they are commonly found in the rectum and are usually asymptomatic. However, they can cause bleeding, abdominal pain, and diarrhea in some cases. There are different types of hamartomas, including juvenile polyps, Peutz-Jeghers polyps, and Cowden syndrome.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Choristoma : a type of benign tumor composed of normal tissue in an abnormal location, e.g. a pancreatic tissue found in the stomach. It is usually asymptomatic but can cause symptoms depending on its location and size. Adenoma : a type of benign tumor composed of glandular tissue. It is usually asymptomatic but can cause symptoms depending on its location and size. If left untreated, it can progress to adenocarcinoma, a malignant tumor. Carcinoma : a type of malignant tumor arising from epithelial cells. It can invade and destroy adjacent tissues and metastasize to distant sites. It can cause various symptoms depending on its location and size.

Extraedge:

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of hamartomas in children, and they are usually located in the rectum. Peutz-Jeghers polyps are also found in the colon and rectum but are associated with a higher risk of developing cancer. Cowden syndrome is a rare genetic condition that increases the risk of developing hamartomas in various organs, including the colon. Hamartomas are usually treated with surgical resection when they cause symptoms or are associated with a higher risk of cancer development.

questions.text: In liver cirrhosis, anastomosis between which of the following is seen?

options.label: A
options.text: Left gastric vein and esophageal vein

questions.correct_answer: A. Left gastric vein and esophageal vein
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left gastric vein and esophageal vein In liver cirrhosis, portal hypertension can develop due to obstruction of blood flow through the liver. The increased pressure in the portal vein can lead to the development of collateral vessels in an attempt to redirect blood flow. One such collateral vessel is the portosystemic venous anastomosis, which can form between veins in the portal venous system and veins in the systemic venous system. Out of the options given, the most common portosystemic venous anastomosis in liver cirrhosis is between the left gastric vein and esophageal vein. This is known as the gastroesophageal varices. Anastomosis between the left and middle colic vein is less common and can lead to the development of colonic varices. Anastomosis between the superior and middle rectal vein (option C) and the inferior and superior rectal vein (option D) can lead to the development of hemorrhoids, which are not typically associated with liver cirrhosis.

Highyeild:

INR, international normalised ratio. Portal hypertension Portal hypertension is a condition where there is an increase in pressure within the portal vein. The portal pressure gradient is used to diagnose portal hypertension, with a gradient greater than 5 mm Hg considered abnormal. Transfemoral-hepatic vein catheterization with a balloon tip catheter is the best method to measure the portal pressure gradient. Collateral vessels develop in response to portal hypertension when the pressure reaches 8-10 mm Hg, where the portal and systemic venous circulations are in close proximity.

Extraedge:

The most clinically significant collateral network is the one that forms between the coronary and short gastric veins to the azygos vein, as it leads to the formation of esophagogastric varices. Other sites of collateralization include the caput medusae, retroperitoneal collateral vessels, and the hemorrhoidal venous plexus.

#MANTRA Esophageal varices Portal hypertension (PHT) leads to the development of GE varices . The most common portosystemic venous anastomosis in liver cirrhosis is between the left gastric vein and esophageal vein. Variceal bleeding is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in PHT. Prophylactic endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) is recommended for medium to large varices . Patients with acute variceal bleeding should be admitted to an ICU for resuscitation and management. Blood resuscitation should be performed until a hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL is reached. Short-term prophylactic antibiotics such as ceftriaxone 1g/day IV decrease the rate of bacterial infections and increase survival. Octreotide is preferred for initial management of acute variceal bleeding. Shunt therapy can control refractory variceal bleeding in >90% of treated individuals. Shunt surgery is considered in patients with preserved hepatic function (CTP class A) , while TIPS is used in patients with decompensated liver disease (CTP class B or C) .

questions.text: A 3 month old child with jaundice and clay Color stool. Bilirubin and ALP found to be raised. Pathology reveals periductal proliferation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

EHBA The given symptoms and pathology findings are suggestive of Extrahepatic Biliary Atresia (EHBA) . EHBA is a rare condition in newborns and infants where the bile ducts outside and/or inside the liver are scarred, blocked, or absent, leading to impaired bile flow and subsequent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and elevated bilirubin and ALP levels. EHBA requires surgical intervention in the form of Kasai portoenterostomy , which is the preferred treatment option for infants less than 3-4 months of age. Without treatment, EHBA can lead to liver failure and cirrhosis.

Highyeild:

Kasai Classification of Biliary Atresia Type of Atresia Description Type I Blockage limited to the CBD Type II Complete blockage of the common hepatic duct Type IIa Patent gallbladder and CBD present Type IIb Gallbladder, cystic duct, and CBD all obstructed Type III Complete obstruction of right and left hepatic ducts and extrahepatic biliary tree

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a chronic liver disease characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts, leading to narrowing and blockage of the ducts. It usually affects adults and is associated with inflammatory bowel disease. Option C: CBD stone is a common cause of obstructive jaundice, but it is less likely in a 3-month-old child. Option D: HCC (Hepatocellular Carcinoma) is a type of liver cancer that usually occurs in adults with underlying liver disease.

Extraedge:

Intraoperative cholangiography is the gold standard for diagnosing biliary atresia. While percutaneous liver biopsy is highly accurate, it cannot provide specific findings for biliary atresia. The preferred treatment for biliary atresia is the Kasai hepatoportoenterostomy, also known as Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. Post-operative cholangitis is the most common complication following Kasai hepatoportoenterostomy.

questions.text: An occasional alcoholic presented with complains of hemetemesis and Malena. He gives history of taking aspirin regularly for osteoarthritis. What is the most likely reason for this presentation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peptic ulcer disease The most likely reason for the presentation of hematemesis and melena in an occasional alcoholic who takes aspirin regularly for osteoarthritis is peptic ulcer disease . Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can cause irritation and damage to the stomach lining, leading to the development of ulcers. In combination with alcohol, which can also irritate the stomach lining, the risk of developing peptic ulcers is even higher. The symptoms of hematemesis (vomiting of blood) and melena (black, tarry stools) are commonly associated with bleeding from a peptic ulcer. Erosive gastritis, esophageal varices, and esophagitis can also cause gastrointestinal bleeding, but they are less likely in this case given the patient's history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption.

Highyeild:

Peptic ulcers are primarily caused by pylori infection or NSAID use . Changes in the prevalence of these factors affect the epidemiology of peptic ulceration. Duodenal ulcers are more common than gastric ulcers, but both can present with similar symptoms. Gastric ulcers can be malignant and may resemble a benign ulcer. Treatment options include gastric antisecretory agents and H. pylori eradication therapy, with elective surgery being a rare option.

Extraedge:

Long-term complications from peptic ulcer surgery can be difficult to manage. Complications of peptic ulcers include perforation, bleeding, and stenosis.

questions.text: A 50 year alcoholic patient presents with history of diarrhea and pain in the right upper abdomen. On further evaluation found to have an abscess in liver which is about 75cc. What is the next line of management
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medical treatment The likely diagnosis for the patient with an abscess in the liver and a history of diarrhea is an amoebic liver abscess . The initial treatment for this condition is medical treatment with metronidazole . The ingestion of Entamoeba histolytica cysts is the cause of intestinal diseases such as diarrhea. The trophozoites then reach the liver through the portal venous system and cause an amebic liver abscess. Common symptoms of this condition include right upper quadrant pain, tenderness, fever, hepatomegaly, and diarrhea. CT scans can differentiate between amoebic and pyogenic abscesses . A rim enhancement is noted in the case of a pyogenic abscess. The main treatment for amebic abscesses is metronidazole , which is curative in over 90% of patients. Luminal agents such as iodoquinol, paromomycin, or diloxanide furoate can be administered to treat the carrier state. Aspiration of the abscess is recommended in cases of diagnostic uncertainty, failure to respond to metronidazole therapy, and abscesses larger than 5 cm in diameter and in the left liver, as they are thought to carry a high risk of rupture.

Highyeild:

Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite with a global distribution that is mainly transmitted through contaminated drinking water. It can cause colonic ulcers that are described as " bottlenecked " due to their considerably undermined edges. These ulcers often have a yellow necrotic floor, from which blood and pus may exude. Amoebiasis can mimic ulcerative colitis clinically, with bloody diarrhea being the most common symptom. Severe complications such as hemorrhage, stricture formation, or perforation of the colon can occur. Pericolitis may result in adhesions that cause intestinal obstruction. Amoebiasis can cause liver abscesses or an amoebic mass (amoeboma) of the caecum or sigmoid, which can be difficult to distinguish from carcinoma. Surgery is risky because the bowel is extremely fragile. Treatment during the acute phase of the disease is with metronidazole , while diloxanide furoate is effective against chronic infections associated with the passage of cysts in stools.

Extraedge:

To diagnose amoebiasis, endoscopic biopsies or fresh stools are examined to look for the presence of amoebae. However, the presence of the parasite does not necessarily indicate that it is pathogenic. It is important to rule out amoebic infection in patients suspected of having ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A CT scan of 53 year old patient is given who presented with abdominal pain .Which of the following statement is correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Etiology is echinococcus The CT image shows a cyst in the liver with wavy membranes within it, indicating the presence of hydatid disease. Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus species of flatworms and primarily affects the liver. Patients with hydatid cysts may be asymptomatic, but when symptomatic, they can present with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice. USG is the initial imaging test used to diagnose the condition, and a CT scan can confirm the diagnosis. CT scan has high accuracy in detecting hydatid cysts, and the serpent sign , which is seen as wavy membranes within the cyst, is a characteristic finding. In addition, USG imaging can show multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance . The ball of wool sign in USG is seen when the contents settle in the dependent portion of the cyst. The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections on USG when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane, resulting in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily. Surgical treatment is effective, but percutaneous aspiration, injection, re-aspiration (PAIR) is also used. Diagnostic tests like IgG ELISA and indirect hemagglutinin assay are used to confirm the diagnosis, and angioembolization is not used in the treatment of hydatid cyst.

Highyeild:

Human echinococcosis is a parasitic disease caused by the larval stages of cestodes belonging to the Echinococcus Surgical intervention may be necessary in cases where medical management fails, with options ranging from liver resection or local excision of cysts to deroofing with evacuation of contents. To prevent contamination of the peritoneal cavity during surgery, it is recommended to continue drug therapy with albendazole and add preoperative praziquantel. Packing the peritoneal cavity with 20% hypertonic saline-soaked packs and instilling 20% hypertonic saline into the cyst before it is opened can help avoid contamination. A biliary communication should be actively sought and sutured during surgery. Packing the space with pedicled greater omentum can reduce the risk of infection and bile leaks. Calcified cysts may be dead, but if there is any doubt about the status of a suspected cyst, it can be monitored with ultrasonography. PAIR is the preferred method of treatment for anatomically and surgically appropriate lesions. PAIR has an efficacy rate of over 75% in managing hydatid cysts. Albendazole is given prophylactically to the patient during the PAIR procedure. Hypertonic (20%) saline is a scolicidal agent used during the procedure that is 100% effective with a contact time of 6 minutes. Other scolicidal agents used during the PAIR procedure includ e 0.5% cetrimide with 0.05% chlorhexidine, absolute alcohol, and 10% povidone iodine.

Extraedge:

The most common symptoms for pyogenic abscess include fever, right upper quadrant tenderness, and raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels . Amebic abscesses may present with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and raised prothrombin time (PT) levels. Hydatid cysts may be asymptomatic or present with abdominal pain, right upper quadrant mass, and eosinophilia.

questions.text: An elderly alcoholic male patient presented to outpatient department with complaints of weight loss. Further evaluation revealed raised conjugated bilirubin, ALP found to be 200IU raised and also found to have markedly raised AFP. What is the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hepatocellular carcinoma AFP is a tumor marker for Hepatocellular carcinoma and it is not a tumor marker for carcinoma gallbladder, cholangiocarcinoma. CA 19-9 is the tumor marker for carcinoma gallbladder and cholangiocarcinoma . Hepatic adenoma is seen in females on oral contraceptive pills.

Highyeild:

Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): Most common primary liver malignancy is HCC HCC represents most common solid organ cancers HCC is the most common malignancy responsible for death in patients with cirrhosis. More prevalent in Asia & sub Saharan Africa ( high frequency of chronic infection with HBV & HCV ) 100 folds increase in risk in individuals with HBV infection More common in males, 60-90% arise in cirrhotic liver Post necrotic cirrhosis has highest risk of developing into HCC Alcoholic cirrhosis & Primary biliary cirrhosis has lower risk Strong propensity for invasion of vascular channels Pathology: Gross Morphology : Hanging, pushing & invasive tumors Histologic patterns : Trabecular, pseudoglandular or acinar, compact pattern and scirrhous pattern Clinical Features: MC symptom is abdominal pain ,weight loss Non-specific symptoms (anorexia, weight loss) and Hepatomegaly Paraneoplastic Syndromes in HCC: Hypercholesterolemia (MC) >hypoglycemia, erythrocytosis, hypercalcemia Vascular bruit (25%), GI bleed (10%), tumor rupture (2-5%), jaundice due to biliary obstruction (10%), paraneoplastic syndrome (<5%).

Extraedge:

Non-invasive diagnostic criteria for HCC include a focal lesion 1-2 cm with two imaging techniques showing arterial hypervascularization and venous washout or a focal lesion >2 cm with one imaging technique showing arterial hypervascularization and venous washout. Complete excision by partial hepatectomy or by total hepatectomy and transplant is the only treatment modality with curative potential. Only 15-20% of HCC is resectable, because rest of the tumors have Multicentricity, Bilobar involvement, Portal vein invasion, Lymphatic metastasis.

questions.text: A patient has swelling in the neck shown in image on further evaluation moving with protrusion of tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyroglossal cyst The most likely diagnosis based on the information provided is thyroglossal cyst . Thyroglossal cysts are congenital abnormalities that occur due to incomplete closure of the thyroglossal duct during embryonic development. They are typically located in the midline of the neck and can move with protrusion of the tongue . Sebaceous cysts, dermoids, and lipomas are also possible differential diagnoses for a neck swelling, but they are not typically associated with movement during tongue protrusion. Further diagnostic evaluation and imaging may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Treatment for thyroglossal duct cysts involves Sistrunk operation , which includes bloc cystectomy and central hyoid bone excision. Approximately 1% of cysts are cancerous, usually papillary type. Total thyroidectomy is advised for patients with large tumors, additional thyroid nodules, and evidence of invasion or metastases. Squamous, Hürthle cell, and anaplastic cancers are rare Medullary thyroid cancers are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts

Extraedge:

The thyroglossal cyst is lined by pseudostratified columnar and squamous epithelium. Heterotopic thyroid tissue is present in 20% of cases.
